messageBody:
Hugh Ekeberg scripsit:

> What about the great stories handed down to generations with the oral
> traditions in every culture. Humans don't need writing to create and
> relate stories. The Qur'an started as an oral tradition for example. Do
> I need to go on. Australian aboriginal religion, songs and stories,
> all oral tradition from the oldest continuous cultures in the world. If
> humans are confined naked in a dark cell, they will find a way to
> make art which when written is literature. But it doesn't have to be
> written to be legitimate.

Absolutely. Literature doesn't require literacy, despite the etymologyical
connection between the words. My point is that no culture has ever
achieved widespread literacy (that is, the situation where the vast majority
of people can read and write their native language) without a standardized
orthography. In can be hideously difficult, but if it is standardized,
it can be taught and people can learn it. Japan and Taiwan both have
very difficult writing systems and adult literacy rates above 99%. In China
proper it's up to 95% now, though this number may be exaggerated for
political reasons, and it's hard to say what actually counts as literacy:
the bar may be quite low.

(The official literacy rate in the U.S. among native-born native speakers
is just short of 100% as well, though the number of people who have
trouble getting basic information from text like warning labels and
signs may be as high as 21% of the total adult population.)
--
